noun.description: A painful feeling of humiliation or distress caused by the consciousness of wrong or foolish behavior.
examples: he felt a pang of shame at telling Alice a lie

verb.description: (of a person, action, or situation) make (someone) feel ashamed.
examples: I tried to shame him into giving some away
synonyms: take down a peg or two

phrases: she puts me to shame, she's so capable
Prague has a public transport system that puts London to shame.
I tend to think of myself as a fairly well-read and knowledgeable fellow, but Lex puts me to shame, with his vast library and conversational skills.
He is putting Hitler to shame by his cold-blooded savagery.
But she certainly puts us to shame at dinner times.
origin: Old English sc(e)amu (noun), sc(e)amian feel shame, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schamen (verb) and German Scham (noun), schämen (verb).
